text:
Here is a 1 minute demo of the time travel debugging feature in Yazz, which is a rapid application development tool in progress at <http://Yazz.com|Yazz.com>. I am not affiliated with the Yazz project, but thought it would be fun for the FoC group to see how some people are attacking that crucial problem of going in reverse. This demo shows a bubble sort, and tracks each line of the code as it executes, and shows the changing state of the data. The concept of having one little square's position vertically be based on the line number of the code doesn't scale well, but for small examples it is very cute.

<https://youtu.be/PKJO1rlJGC4>

elements.text: Here is a 1 minute demo of the time travel debugging feature in Yazz, which is a rapid application development tool in progress at
Yazz.com

. I am not affiliated with the Yazz project, but thought it would be fun for the FoC group to see how some people are attacking that crucial problem of going in reverse. This demo shows a bubble sort, and tracks each line of the code as it executes, and shows the changing state of the data. The concept of having one little square's position vertically be based on the line number of the code doesn't scale well, but for small examples it is very cute.

text:
<@UEQ6M68H0> Do I interpret the “dot chart” correctly: x axis is time and y axis is line number (from top to bottom, just like the source code)? Not sure how insightful that is, but it certainly is a clever idea to get to a visualization with relatively simple means.

Funny how we are so attached to line numbers… Xcode shows code coverage as color coded boxes with optional counts per line. That sometimes means there are multiple branches/scopes in a single line. That’s not ideal, but at least you have the code right there. If you detach the visualization from the code it seems there should be something better than lines to visualize as atoms.

elements.text: Do I interpret the “dot chart” correctly: x axis is time and y axis is line number (from top to bottom, just like the source code)? Not sure how insightful that is, but it certainly is a clever idea to get to a visualization with relatively simple means.

Funny how we are so attached to line numbers… Xcode shows code coverage as color coded boxes with optional counts per line. That sometimes means there are multiple branches/scopes in a single line. That’s not ideal, but at least you have the code right there. If you detach the visualization from the code it seems there should be something better than lines to visualize as atoms.

text: I think this idea comes from Bret Victor's Learnable Programming. I know that's where I stole it from for my project!

elements.text: I think this idea comes from Bret Victor's Learnable Programming. I know that's where I stole it from for my project!

text: The way I implemented it was to save list of all mutations, and then every 200k mutations save a full snapshot of the objects state. To recover a state, jump to the nearest snapshot then replay at most 200k mutations. Takes about 30ms in my case and doesn't use much too much memory

elements.text: The way I implemented it was to save list of all mutations, and then every 200k mutations save a full snapshot of the objects state. To recover a state, jump to the nearest snapshot then replay at most 200k mutations. Takes about 30ms in my case and doesn't use much too much memory

text: Ok, yep, I made the Yazz time travel thing. It was a total rip off of Chris Knott's work which I saw on hacker news. I thought, whoooa, that is amazing

text: anyway, while I love the debugger, in the real world people don't use it much. So right now I am building something called "Edit And Continue" debugging, like in VB6

text: One of the most frustrating things for me when I was a programmer was stepping through something then realising I had missed the key moment (where my expectations had diverged from the actual execution). Finding this moment is the key to begin understanding what's gone wrong, but it can be hard and slow to do.

elements.text: One of the most frustrating things for me when I was a programmer was stepping through something then realising I had missed the key moment (where my expectations had diverged from the actual execution). Finding this moment is the key to begin understanding what's gone wrong, but it can be hard and slow to do.

text: If you had to pick one direction for debugging, forward or reverse, you would definitely pick reverse because debugging is the process of going back in time from unexpected result to cause, yet almost all debuggers go forwards only

elements.text: If you had to pick one direction for debugging, forward or reverse, you would definitely pick reverse because debugging is the process of going back in time from unexpected result to cause, yet almost all debuggers go forwards only

text: My favourite snippet of everything I have come across FoC related is BV when he says something like "the people we think of as good programmers are just those people who are good at playing computer" (because what you have to do is read code and execute it in your head). The timeline visualisation is really just one example, put it's good because it pulls something out of the programmer's head and make is visible.

elements.text: My favourite snippet of everything I have come across FoC related is BV when he says something like "the people we think of as good programmers are just those people who are good at playing computer" (because what you have to do is read code and execute it in your head). text: True, it would make sense to pick reverse. But, seeing how people used yazz in real life, everyone said they wanted an interactive debugger. I was surprised that noone actually used the time travelling feature. It seemed like a good party piece at demos, but in practice people didn't use it

elements.text: True, it would make sense to pick reverse. But, seeing how people used yazz in real life, everyone said they wanted an interactive debugger. I was surprised that noone actually used the time travelling feature. It seemed like a good party piece at demos, but in practice people didn't use it
